documents.name: Snake Bite
documents.description: Wound caused by snake teeth, potentially involving venom injection
documents.notes: Don't apply tourniquet, cut wound, suck out venom, or apply ice
steps: Keep victim calm and still
Remove jewelry/tight items near bite
Clean wound gently
Immobilize affected limb at heart level
Mark swelling edge and note time
Transport to hospital immediately

documents.name: Animal Bites
documents.description: Wounds from animal teeth that may cause tissue damage and infection
documents.notes: Risk of rabies and tetanus requires medical follow-up
steps: Wash wound thoroughly with soap and water
Control bleeding with direct pressure
Apply antiseptic if available
Cover with clean bandage
Seek medical help, especially for deep wounds

documents.name: Insect Stings
documents.description: Puncture wounds from insects that inject venom
documents.notes: Seek emergency help for allergic reactions: difficulty breathing, swelling of face/throat, dizziness
steps: Remove stinger if visible (scrape, don't squeeze)
Wash area with soap and water
Apply cold compress
Take antihistamine if available
Watch for signs of severe allergic reaction

documents.name: Cardiac Arrest
documents.description: When the heart stops pumping blood effectively, causing unconsciousness and no normal breathing
documents.notes: Compression depth: 5-6cm at rate of 100-120 per minute
steps: Check responsiveness
Call for emergency help
Begin CPR immediately: 30 chest compressions followed by 2 rescue breaths
Continue until help arrives or victim shows signs of life
If available, use AED following its instructions

documents.name: Chest Pain
documents.description: Discomfort or pain in chest that may indicate serious heart problems
documents.notes: Pain may radiate to arm, jaw, back or stomach
steps: Help person into comfortable position (usually sitting, leaning forward)
Call for emergency help
If person has prescribed medication (like nitroglycerin), help them take it
Loosen tight clothing
Monitor breathing and consciousness
Be prepared to perform CPR if needed

documents.name: Severe Bleeding
documents.description: Significant blood loss that can lead to shock and be life-threatening
documents.notes: Do not remove embedded objects from wounds
steps: Apply direct pressure to wound with clean cloth/bandage
If possible, elevate injured area above heart level
Add more bandages if blood soaks through (don't remove original bandage)
If bleeding continues, apply pressure to appropriate pressure point
Secure bandages firmly
Treat for shock
Seek medical help urgently

documents.name: Shock
documents.description: A life-threatening condition when body isn't getting enough blood flow, causing vital organs to not function properly
documents.notes: Signs include: pale skin, rapid breathing, weak pulse, confusion
steps: Lay person flat on back
Elevate legs 30cm if no spinal injury suspected
Keep person warm with blankets
Loosen tight clothing
Don't give food or drink
Monitor breathing and consciousness
Seek immediate medical help

documents.name: Heat Exhaustion
documents.description: Condition resulting from excessive heat exposure and dehydration
documents.notes: Signs: heavy sweating, cool/moist skin, headache, nausea, dizziness
steps: Move to cool place
Remove excess clothing
Lie down with legs elevated
Apply cool, wet cloths to body
Sip water slowly
If no improvement in 30 minutes, seek medical help

documents.name: Heat Stroke
documents.description: Life-threatening condition when body temperature rises dangerously high
documents.notes: Signs: hot/dry skin, high body temperature, confusion, possible unconsciousness
steps: Call for emergency help
Move to cool place
Remove excess clothing
Cool body rapidly with water/ice packs to neck, armpits, groin
Monitor breathing and consciousness

documents.name: Hypothermia
documents.description: Dangerous drop in body temperature below 35°C (95°F)
documents.notes: Don't warm extremities first or use direct heat sources
steps: Move to warm place
Remove wet clothing
Warm center of body first with blankets
If conscious, give warm (not hot) beverages
Monitor breathing
Seek medical help

documents.name: Frostbite
documents.description: Freezing of body tissues, usually extremities, due to extreme cold
documents.notes: Affected areas may be numb, waxy-looking, and discolored
steps: Move to warm place
Don't rub affected area
Immerse in warm (not hot) water
Don't use direct heat sources
Don't break blisters
Seek medical help

documents.name: Fractures
documents.description: A break or crack in a bone caused by trauma or medical conditions
documents.notes: Don't attempt to realign bones or push protruding bones back
steps: Immobilize injury site including joints above and below
Apply cold compress to reduce swelling
For open fractures, cover wound with clean dressing before immobilizing
Support injury in position found or most comfortable
Check circulation beyond injury site
Seek medical help

documents.name: Sprains and Strains
documents.description: Injuries to ligaments (sprains) or muscles/tendons (strains) from overstretching or tearing
documents.notes: Remember RICE: Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation
steps: Rest the injured area
Apply ice pack for 20 minutes every 2-3 hours
Compress with elastic bandage
Elevate the injured part
Take pain relievers if needed
Seek medical attention if severe

documents.name: Head Injury
documents.description: Trauma to the head that may affect brain function
documents.notes: Don't shake person to wake them or remove objects impaled in head
steps: Assess consciousness and breathing
If unconscious but breathing, place in recovery position
Control any bleeding with gentle pressure
Apply cold compress to swelling
Monitor for changes in consciousness, vomiting, unequal pupils
Seek medical help, especially if loss of consciousness occurred

documents.name: Cuts and Abrasions
documents.description: Breaks in the skin ranging from minor scrapes to deep cuts
documents.notes: Signs of infection: increasing pain, redness, swelling, warmth, pus
steps: Clean hands before treating
Clean wound with clean water
Remove any dirt or debris
Apply antiseptic if available
Cover with sterile dressing
Apply pressure if bleeding
Seek medical help for deep cuts, embedded objects, or signs of infection

documents.name: Burns
documents.description: Tissue damage from heat, chemicals, electricity, radiation or friction
documents.notes: Classify by degrees: 1st (red skin), 2nd (blisters), 3rd (white/charred skin)
steps: Remove from source of burn
Cool burn with cool (not cold) running water for 10-20 minutes
Remove jewelry/tight items from burned area
Cover with clean, non-stick bandage
Don't apply butter, toothpaste or home remedies
Seek medical help for severe or large burns

documents.name: Eye Injuries
documents.description: Damage to the eye from impact, foreign objects, or chemicals
documents.notes: Never rub eyes or try to remove embedded objects
steps: For chemical splashes: Flush with clean water for 15-20 minutes
For foreign objects: Don't rub eye, try blinking or gentle rinsing
For impacts: Apply cold compress without pressure
For embedded objects: Don't remove, stabilize and seek help
Cover both eyes to prevent movement

documents.name: Nosebleed
documents.description: Bleeding from the nose, often from trauma, dry air, or medical conditions
documents.notes: Seek help if bleeding doesn't stop after 20 minutes or is extremely heavy
steps: Sit upright, leaning slightly forward
Pinch soft part of nose for 10-15 minutes
Breathe through mouth
Apply cold compress to bridge of nose
Avoid blowing nose for several hours after bleeding stops

documents.name: Stroke
documents.description: Brain damage from interrupted blood flow causing sudden neurological symptoms
documents.notes: Time is critical - immediate medical attention needed
steps: Use FAST check: Face drooping, Arm weakness, Speech difficulties, Time to call emergency
Note time symptoms started
Keep person comfortable
Don't give food or drink
Position on affected side if unconscious but breathing

documents.name: Seizures
documents.description: Sudden, uncontrolled electrical disturbance in the brain causing changes in behavior, movements, or consciousness
documents.notes: Seek help if first seizure, lasts >5 minutes, or person doesn't regain consciousness
steps: Protect from injury by clearing area
Don't restrain person
Don't put anything in mouth
Time the seizure
After seizure, place in recovery position if unconscious but breathing
Stay until fully recovered

documents.name: Diabetic Emergencies
documents.description: Complications from abnormal blood sugar levels in diabetics
documents.notes: High blood sugar: excessive thirst, frequent urination, fruity breath; Low blood sugar: confusion, weakness, hunger
steps: If conscious and symptoms suggest low blood sugar, give sugar source (juice, honey)
If unconscious but breathing, place in recovery position
Don't give anything by mouth if unconscious
Call for emergency help

documents.name: Poisoning
documents.description: Harmful effects from swallowing, inhaling, injecting, or absorbing toxic substances
documents.notes: Bring substance container or name to hospital if possible
steps: Call poison control center
Remove person from source if inhalation
Remove contaminated clothing for skin exposure
Rinse skin with water for 15-20 minutes if skin exposure
Don't induce vomiting unless directed by medical professionals

documents.name: Allergic Reaction
documents.description: Severe overreaction of immune system to allergen, potentially life-threatening
documents.notes: Severe signs: difficulty breathing, swelling of face/throat, rapid pulse, dizziness
steps: Call for emergency help for severe reactions
Help use epinephrine auto-injector if available and prescribed
Help take antihistamine if mild reaction
Keep calm and still
If breathing difficulty, help into position that eases breathing

documents.name: Choking
documents.description: A life-threatening emergency when a foreign object blocks the airway, preventing normal breathing
documents.notes: For babies under 1 year: Use 5 back blows followed by 5 chest thrusts instead of abdominal thrusts
steps: Ask "Are you choking?"
If person can cough, encourage them to keep coughing
If unable to speak/cough: Stand behind, support chest, bend forward
Give 5 firm back blows between shoulder blades
If unsuccessful, give 5 abdominal thrusts
Alternate between 5 back blows and 5 abdominal thrusts until object is expelled
If person becomes unconscious, begin CPR

documents.name: Drowning
documents.description: Respiratory impairment from submersion in liquid causing asphyxia by water, weeds or mud entering lungs
documents.notes: Hypothermia is a common complication - keep victim warm
steps: Ensure your safety first
Remove victim from water without endangering yourself
Check breathing
If breathing, place in recovery position and keep warm
If not breathing, begin CPR immediately
Do not try to remove water from lungs
Transport to healthcare facility urgently

documents.name: Asthma Attack
documents.description: A condition where airways narrow, swell and produce extra mucus, making breathing difficult
documents.notes: Severe attacks can be life-threatening
steps: Help the person to sit upright in comfortable position
Assist with using their inhaler if available
Encourage slow, deep breathing
Loosen tight clothing
If no improvement after inhaler use or symptoms worsen, seek emergency medical help

documents.name: Suffocation
documents.description: Inability to breathe due to lack of oxygen, often from smoke, gases or airway compression
documents.notes: Carbon monoxide is especially dangerous as it's colorless and odorless
steps: Ensure your safety first
Remove victim from danger area
For smoke: stay low, use wet cloth over mouth if entering area
For gases: determine if lighter or heavier than air and approach accordingly
Ensure fresh air circulation
Loosen victim's clothing
Begin CPR if not breathing
Transport to healthcare facility

documents.name: Emergency Childbirth
documents.description: Unexpected delivery of baby outside medical setting
documents.notes: Keep both mother and baby warm
steps: Call for emergency help
Help mother into comfortable position
Wash hands thoroughly
Place clean materials under mother
Support baby's head as it emerges
Clear baby's airway if needed
Dry and warm baby
Place baby on mother's chest
Don't pull on umbilical cord

documents.name: Psychological First Aid
documents.description: Humane, supportive response to fellow human suffering and who may need support
documents.notes: Don't pressure to tell their story or give advice instead of listening
steps: Approach calmly and introduce yourself
Provide practical care and support
Listen attentively without pressure
Comfort and help person feel calm
Help connect to information, services, social supports
Protect from further harm

documents.name: CPR
documents.description: Emergency procedure combining chest compressions and rescue breaths to maintain circulation and oxygenation
documents.notes: For children: use less force; For infants: use 2 fingers for compressions
steps: Check responsiveness
Call for emergency help
Place on hard surface
Give 30 chest compressions (5-6cm deep, 100-120/minute)
Give 2 rescue breaths
Continue 30:2 ratio until help arrives or signs of life return

documents.name: Tick Bite
documents.description: Bite from a tick that may transmit infections like Lyme disease
documents.notes: Don't crush or twist the tick body during removal
steps: Use fine-tipped tweezers to grasp tick close to skin
Pull upward steadily without twisting
Clean bite area with soap and water or antiseptic
Dispose of tick in sealed container or alcohol
Monitor for rash, fever or flu-like symptoms and seek medical care if they appear

documents.name: Scorpion Sting
documents.description: Painful sting from a scorpion that may inject venom
documents.notes: Children and older adults are at higher risk for severe reactions
steps: Move person to safe area away from scorpion
Wash sting site with soap and water
Apply cold compress wrapped in cloth
Keep affected limb immobilized and at heart level
Seek medical attention, especially for severe pain, numbness or breathing difficulty

documents.name: Spider Bite (Non‑Venomous)
documents.description: Localized skin reaction from most common, non‑venomous spiders
documents.notes: Most bites cause minor irritation and heal without complications
steps: Clean area with soap and water
Apply cold compress to reduce pain and swelling
Elevate affected limb if swollen
Take over‑the‑counter pain relievers or antihistamines if needed
Seek medical care if symptoms worsen or signs of infection appear

documents.name: Spider Bite (Suspected Venomous)
documents.description: Potentially serious bite from venomous spiders that can cause systemic symptoms
documents.notes: If safe, note spider appearance or take a photo for identification
steps: Move person away from area where spider was found
Clean bite gently with soap and water
Apply cold compress intermittently
Keep affected limb lowered or at heart level
Seek urgent medical attention, especially for severe pain, muscle cramps or spreading redness

documents.name: Jellyfish Sting
documents.description: Sting from jellyfish tentacles that inject venom into the skin
documents.notes: Different species need different treatments; local guidelines should be followed
steps: Move person out of water to safe place
Avoid rubbing the affected area
Rinse tentacles off using seawater, not fresh water
Carefully remove visible tentacles with tweezers or gloved hand
Immerse affected area in hot water (not scalding) if recommended locally
Seek medical help if pain is severe or there are systemic symptoms like breathing difficulty

documents.name: Fish Spine or Sea Urchin Injury
documents.description: Puncture wounds from fish spines or sea urchin spines
documents.notes: Some spines may break off and remain embedded in the skin
steps: Rinse wound with clean water or saline
Soak affected area in warm water to ease pain if appropriate
Do not attempt to dig out deeply embedded spines
Cover with clean dressing
Seek medical care for removal and to prevent infection

documents.name: Leech Bite
documents.description: Attachment of a leech to the skin that feeds on blood
documents.notes: Pulling forcefully may leave mouthparts in the skin
steps: Avoid pulling the leech directly
Use fingernail, credit card edge or blunt object to gently slide under its mouth to detach
Once removed, wash area with soap and water
Apply antiseptic and small dressing
Monitor for prolonged bleeding or infection and seek care if needed

documents.name: Fainting (Syncope)
documents.description: Brief loss of consciousness due to temporary reduction in blood flow to the brain
documents.notes: Often short‑lived but can signal underlying problems
steps: Lay person flat on back
Elevate legs about 30cm if no injury suspected
Loosen tight clothing
Check breathing and responsiveness
If unconscious for more than a minute or symptoms persist, seek medical help

documents.name: Palpitations
documents.description: Awareness of abnormal, rapid or irregular heartbeats
documents.notes: Palpitations with chest pain, dizziness or fainting can be serious
steps: Help person sit or lie down in a comfortable position
Encourage slow, deep breathing to reduce anxiety
Ask about any known heart conditions or medications
Avoid stimulants such as caffeine and energy drinks
Seek medical assessment if symptoms are severe, recurrent or associated with chest pain or fainting

documents.name: High Blood Pressure Crisis (Suspected)
documents.description: Very high blood pressure that may cause severe headache, chest pain or neurological symptoms
documents.notes: Home blood pressure devices can help confirm high readings if available
steps: Have person sit upright and stay calm
Loosen tight clothing
Ask if they have prescribed blood pressure medication and assist with taking it as directed
Do not give extra doses beyond prescription
Seek urgent medical care if severe headache, visual changes, chest pain or weakness occur

documents.name: Low Blood Pressure (Hypotension)
documents.description: Blood pressure that is too low to supply adequate blood flow to organs
documents.notes: Can result from dehydration, blood loss or medications
steps: Have person lie down flat
Elevate legs if no injury, spinal problem or breathing difficulty
Loosen tight clothing
Offer small sips of water if fully conscious and not at risk of vomiting
Seek medical help if symptoms persist or person has chest pain, shortness of breath or confusion

documents.name: Chest Trauma (Blunt)
documents.description: Injury to chest wall or organs from a blow or compression
documents.notes: Can cause internal bleeding or lung damage even without visible wounds
steps: Assess breathing and level of consciousness
Help person find a position that eases breathing, usually semi‑sitting
Support injured side with a folded cloth or pillow
Avoid tightly binding chest which may restrict breathing
Seek urgent medical care, especially if breathing is painful, shallow or fast

documents.name: Penetrating Chest Wound
documents.description: Open wound to chest from objects like knives or bullets
documents.notes: Removing embedded objects can worsen bleeding and collapse lung
steps: Do not remove any embedded object
Apply bulky dressing around object to stabilize it
If there is an open wound without embedded object, cover with sterile dressing and tape on three sides to allow air to escape
Position person with injured side down if it eases breathing
Seek emergency medical help immediately

documents.name: Sunburn
documents.description: Skin damage from excessive exposure to ultraviolet radiation
documents.notes: Repeated sunburns increase risk of skin cancer
steps: Move out of sun into shade or indoors
Cool skin with cool compresses or cool bath
Apply soothing lotion like aloe vera if available
Encourage oral fluids to prevent dehydration
Seek medical help if blistering is extensive, there is fever or signs of dehydration

documents.name: Dehydration
documents.description: Loss of more fluids than taken in, reducing body’s ability to function
documents.notes: Severe dehydration is a medical emergency, especially in children and older adults
steps: Move person to cool, shaded area
Give small, frequent sips of water or oral rehydration solution
Avoid very sugary or caffeinated drinks
Monitor for confusion, rapid pulse or lack of sweating
Seek medical help if unable to keep fluids down or if symptoms are severe

documents.name: Lightning Strike
documents.description: Injury from direct or nearby lightning strike carrying massive electrical energy
documents.notes: Multiple victims may be affected; those without signs of life should be prioritized for CPR
steps: Ensure scene is safe; lightning can strike again
Check responsiveness and breathing immediately
Begin CPR if no normal breathing
Treat visible burns and injuries with clean dressings
Seek emergency medical help for all lightning strike victims

documents.name: Avalanche or Snow Burial
documents.description: Burial or compression under snow following an avalanche or collapse
documents.notes: Risk of suffocation, trauma and hypothermia is high
steps: Ensure area is safe from further avalanches
Mark last seen point and begin systematic search if trained
Once located, uncover face and clear airway first
Check breathing and circulation
Protect from cold and handle gently to avoid triggering cardiac arrest
Seek emergency medical help immediately

documents.name: Minor Chemical Exposure (Skin)
documents.description: Contact of skin with mildly irritating chemicals like detergents or diluted acids
documents.notes: Always check container label for specific first aid advice
steps: Remove contaminated clothing and jewelry
Rinse affected skin with running water for at least 15 minutes
Avoid using neutralizing chemicals unless advised by professionals
Cover with clean, dry dressing if skin is damaged
Seek medical care if pain, redness or blistering persists

documents.name: Serious Chemical Exposure (Skin or Eyes)
documents.description: Contact with corrosive chemicals that can cause deep burns or eye damage
documents.notes: Alkalis can cause deeper injury than acids and may feel less painful initially
steps: Ensure personal safety before assisting
Flush affected area with large amounts of running water immediately
For eyes, hold eyelids open and rinse continuously for at least 15-20 minutes
Remove contaminated clothing while rinsing
Seek emergency medical attention promptly

documents.name: Crush Injury
documents.description: Damage to body tissues from prolonged pressure by heavy objects
documents.notes: Releasing a crushed limb after long compression can cause sudden shock
steps: Ensure scene safety before approaching
Call for emergency help
If object is light and safe, carefully remove it
If limb has been trapped for a long time, wait for professional help before lifting heavy objects
Control bleeding and cover wounds with sterile dressings
Monitor for signs of shock

documents.name: Amputation (Partial or Complete)
documents.description: Loss of part of a limb or body part due to injury
documents.notes: Proper handling of amputated part increases chance of surgical reattachment
steps: Call emergency medical services immediately
Control bleeding from stump using direct pressure and dressings
Wrap amputated part in sterile or clean cloth
Place wrapped part in waterproof bag, then put bag on ice or in cold water (do not place directly on ice)
Label with time and send with patient to hospital

documents.name: Joint Dislocation
documents.description: Separation of bones that normally meet at a joint
documents.notes: Forcing joint back into place can cause serious damage
steps: Support injured joint in position found using padding or sling
Apply cold compress to reduce swelling and pain
Do not attempt to reposition the joint
Check circulation and sensation beyond injury
Seek prompt medical attention

documents.name: Soft Tissue Bruise (Contusion)
documents.description: Bleeding under the skin due to blunt impact, causing discoloration and tenderness
documents.notes: Large or unexplained bruises can indicate underlying medical issues
steps: Apply cold pack wrapped in cloth for 15-20 minutes
Elevate bruised area if possible
Avoid massaging the area
Monitor for increased swelling or severe pain
Seek medical advice if bruise is very large, painful or associated with suspected fracture

documents.name: Puncture Wound
documents.description: Deep, narrow wound caused by sharp objects such as nails or needles
documents.notes: High risk of infection due to depth and difficulty in cleaning
steps: Allow minor bleeding to help flush out debris
Gently wash area with soap and water
Do not probe the wound or remove deeply embedded objects
Cover with clean, sterile dressing
Seek medical care, especially if object was dirty or tetanus vaccination is not current

documents.name: Blister (Friction)
documents.description: Fluid‑filled bubble on skin caused by repeated friction or rubbing
documents.notes: Intact blisters protect underlying skin and reduce infection risk
steps: Clean area with mild soap and water
Leave small, intact blisters unbroken when possible
Cover with protective dressing or blister pad
If large and painful, sterilize needle and drain fluid from edge without removing top skin
Apply antiseptic and clean dressing

documents.name: Finger or Toe Jam
documents.description: Impact injury to finger or toe causing pain and swelling at a joint
documents.notes: May involve sprain or fracture
steps: Apply ice pack wrapped in cloth for 15-20 minutes
Elevate affected hand or foot
Buddy‑tape injured finger or toe to adjacent one if not deformed
Avoid putting weight on painful toe
Seek medical care if deformity, severe pain or inability to move joint is present

documents.name: Embedded Object in Wound
documents.description: Foreign object lodged in wound such as glass, metal or wood
documents.notes: Removing object can increase bleeding and damage tissues
steps: Do not remove embedded object
Stabilize object by padding around it with cloth or dressings
Apply bandages to hold padding and object in place
Control bleeding by pressing around, not on, the object
Seek immediate medical attention

documents.name: Fever (Adult)
documents.description: Elevated body temperature often due to infection or inflammation
documents.notes: Very high fever or associated confusion requires urgent assessment
steps: Measure temperature if thermometer is available
Encourage rest and light clothing
Offer plenty of fluids
Use fever‑reducing medicine only as directed on label or by doctor
Seek medical help if fever is very high, lasts more than a couple of days or is accompanied by severe symptoms

documents.name: Fever (Child)
documents.description: Raised body temperature in infants and children
documents.notes: Infants under 3 months with fever should be seen by a doctor quickly
steps: Check temperature with appropriate thermometer for child’s age
Keep child in light clothing and comfortable room temperature
Offer frequent fluids like breast milk, formula or water as appropriate
Do not give adult medicines to children
Seek urgent medical help for difficulty breathing, rash, persistent vomiting, seizures or if child is very drowsy

documents.name: Gastroenteritis (Vomiting and Diarrhea)
documents.description: Inflammation of stomach and intestines causing vomiting and diarrhea
documents.notes: Main risk is dehydration, especially in children and older adults
steps: Encourage small, frequent sips of oral rehydration solution or clear fluids
Avoid solid foods until vomiting improves, then introduce bland foods slowly
Encourage handwashing to prevent spread
Do not give anti‑diarrheal medicines to young children without medical advice
Seek medical care if blood is present in stool, high fever or signs of dehydration occur

documents.name: Abdominal Pain (Unknown Cause)
documents.description: Pain anywhere between chest and groin with many possible causes
documents.notes: Severe, sudden or persistent abdominal pain can indicate serious conditions
steps: Have person rest in comfortable position
Avoid giving food, drink or painkillers unless needed and not contraindicated
Observe for worsening pain, vomiting, fever or inability to pass stool or gas
Do not apply strong heat to abdomen
Seek medical evaluation if pain is severe, localized, persistent or associated with fainting

documents.name: Migraine or Severe Headache
documents.description: Intense headache often with nausea, sensitivity to light or sound
documents.notes: Headaches with sudden onset, confusion or weakness require urgent care
steps: Move to quiet, dark room if possible
Encourage rest and relaxation
Offer usual prescribed or over‑the‑counter pain medication if appropriate
Apply cool cloth to forehead
Seek medical attention if headache is sudden, worst ever, or associated with weakness, confusion, fever or stiff neck

documents.name: Hyperventilation (Rapid Breathing)
documents.description: Breathing too quickly, often from anxiety or panic, causing dizziness and tingling
documents.notes: Underlying medical causes such as asthma or heart problems must be considered
steps: Reassure person and encourage slow, controlled breathing
Ask them to breathe in through nose and out through pursed lips
Encourage counting slowly while breathing (for example 4 in, 6 out)
Remove person from stressful situation if possible
Seek medical care if chest pain, bluish lips or confusion are present

documents.name: Food Allergy Reaction
documents.description: Immune reaction after eating certain foods, ranging from mild to life‑threatening
documents.notes: Anaphylaxis is a medical emergency requiring immediate treatment
steps: Stop eating the suspected food immediately
For mild reactions, give antihistamine if available and previously used
Monitor for swelling of lips, tongue or throat, breathing difficulty or dizziness
Use prescribed epinephrine auto‑injector if severe symptoms develop
Call emergency services for any signs of anaphylaxis

documents.name: Menstrual Cramps (Severe Dysmenorrhea)
documents.description: Painful cramping in lower abdomen during menstruation
documents.notes: New or unusually severe pain can indicate other conditions
steps: Encourage rest in a comfortable position
Apply warm pack to lower abdomen if available
Use over‑the‑counter pain relief if appropriate and not contraindicated
Encourage hydration and light activity such as gentle stretching
Seek medical advice if pain is severe, worsening or associated with unusual bleeding

documents.name: Constipation
documents.description: Difficult or infrequent bowel movements often with hard stools
documents.notes: Sudden severe abdominal pain with constipation may need urgent assessment
steps: Encourage increased fluid intake unless restricted
Suggest high‑fiber foods such as fruits, vegetables and whole grains
Encourage gentle physical activity like walking
Avoid excessive use of laxatives without medical advice
Seek medical help if constipation lasts more than several days or is accompanied by abdominal pain, vomiting or blood in stool

documents.name: Nose Inhalation of Foreign Body (Child)
documents.description: Small object stuck in nostril, often in young children
documents.notes: Home removal attempts can push object further in
steps: Keep child calm and discourage probing nose with fingers or tools
Do not insert cotton swabs or instruments into nostril
Have child breathe through mouth
If visible and easily grasped, adult may gently remove with tweezers, but avoid blind attempts
Seek medical attention for safe removal

documents.name: Foreign Body in Throat (Mild Obstruction)
documents.description: Foreign object partially blocking airway but person can still cough or speak
documents.notes: Strong coughing is body’s way to clear obstruction
steps: Encourage person to continue coughing forcefully
Advise them to spit out object if it reaches mouth
Do not slap back unless coughing becomes ineffective
Stay with person and monitor breathing
Seek medical review if discomfort persists or object is not expelled

documents.name: Smoke Inhalation (Minor)
documents.description: Breathing in smoke causing irritation to airways and eyes
documents.notes: Even minor exposure can worsen existing lung disease
steps: Move person to fresh air immediately
Help them sit upright in comfortable position
Loosen tight clothing around neck and chest
Rinse eyes with clean water if irritated
Seek medical help if persistent cough, wheezing or difficulty breathing occurs

documents.name: Hyperventilation from Panic Attack
documents.description: Rapid breathing caused by intense anxiety, leading to dizziness and tingling
documents.notes: Symptoms can mimic heart attack or asthma
steps: Speak calmly and reassuringly to person
Encourage slow inhalation through nose and longer exhalation through mouth
Ask them to focus on counting breaths or an object in the room
Remove or reduce crowd and noise if possible
Seek medical assistance if chest pain or collapse occurs or if first episode

documents.name: Minor Nose Irritation from Inhaled Irritant
documents.description: Burning or irritation in nose and throat after inhaling mild irritants like cleaning fumes
documents.notes: Prolonged exposure can lead to more serious lung problems
steps: Move away from source of fumes to fresh air
Open windows and doors to ventilate area if safe
Rinse mouth and nose gently with clean water
Avoid re‑exposure to irritant
Seek medical care if coughing, wheezing or shortness of breath develops

documents.name: Breathing Difficulty in Child (Non‑Specific)
documents.description: Increased work of breathing in a child due to many possible causes
documents.notes: Children can deteriorate quickly when breathing is compromised
steps: Sit child upright or in position that eases breathing
Loosen tight clothing around chest and neck
Keep child calm and avoid unnecessary movement
Use prescribed inhalers or nebulizers if asthma is known and medication available
Seek urgent medical attention for noisy breathing, chest retractions or bluish lips

documents.name: Croup (Barking Cough in Child)
documents.description: Viral illness in young children causing barking cough and noisy breathing
documents.notes: Breathing can suddenly worsen at night
steps: Keep child calm; crying can worsen symptoms
Sit them upright on caregiver’s lap
Offer cool or humidified air if available
Avoid throat lozenges in very young children due to choking risk
Seek medical care if breathing is labored, noisy at rest or child appears very unwell

documents.name: Spinal Injury (Suspected)
documents.description: Damage or suspected damage to bones or cord of spine
documents.notes: Movement may worsen spinal cord damage
steps: Instruct person not to move head, neck or back
Support head and neck in position found using hands or padding
Do not straighten or twist spine
Call for emergency help
Monitor breathing and be prepared to provide CPR without moving neck excessively

documents.name: Pelvic Injury
documents.description: Injury to pelvic bones often from high‑energy trauma
documents.notes: May involve severe internal bleeding
steps: Advise person to remain still and lie flat if possible
Avoid moving legs apart or rotating hips
Place padding under knees to slightly bend hips if comfortable
Treat for shock with warmth and reassurance
Seek emergency medical help immediately

documents.name: Dental Trauma (Broken or Knocked‑Out Tooth)
documents.description: Injury to teeth or surrounding tissues from impact
documents.notes: Quick action can sometimes save a knocked‑out adult tooth
steps: Control mouth bleeding with clean gauze or cloth
If adult tooth is completely knocked out, handle by crown, not root
Rinse tooth gently with clean water if dirty, do not scrub
Try to place tooth back into socket and have person bite gently on cloth, or store tooth in milk or saline
Seek urgent dental care

documents.name: Ear Foreign Body
documents.description: Object stuck in ear canal such as bead, insect or cotton tip
documents.notes: Using tools can push object deeper or damage ear
steps: Ask person not to poke ear with fingers or objects
Do not attempt removal with cotton swabs or sharp instruments
If insect is suspected, tilt head and gently pour warm (not hot) clean oil if not allergic and eardrum is likely intact
Allow insect to float out, then drain oil
Seek medical care for safe removal

documents.name: Eye Chemical Splash
documents.description: Chemical accidentally splashed into one or both eyes
documents.notes: Immediate and prolonged irrigation is critical
steps: Hold eyelids open with clean fingers
Rinse eye with running clean water or saline for at least 15-20 minutes
Tilt head so affected eye is lower and liquid flows away from other eye
Remove contact lenses if easily possible during rinsing
Seek emergency medical care promptly after rinsing

documents.name: Foreign Body in Eye (Surface)
documents.description: Small particles on surface of eye or under eyelid causing irritation
documents.notes: Rubbing may scratch the cornea
steps: Ask person to blink several times to encourage object to wash out
Rinse eye with clean water or saline while holding eyelids open
Check under upper eyelid by gently pulling it down over lower lid and releasing
Do not use sharp objects or cotton swabs on eye surface
Seek medical care if pain, tearing or blurred vision persists

documents.name: Epistaxis in Child (Nosebleed)
documents.description: Bleeding from nose in children, often due to nose picking or minor trauma
documents.notes: Tilting head back can cause blood to be swallowed
steps: Have child sit up and lean slightly forward
Pinch soft part of nose just below bridge for 10 minutes
Encourage breathing through mouth
After bleeding stops, advise avoiding nose blowing or picking for several hours
Seek medical help if bleeding is heavy or recurs frequently

documents.name: Panic Attack Support
documents.description: Sudden episode of intense fear with physical symptoms like palpitations and breathlessness
documents.notes: Symptoms can mimic serious physical illness
steps: Stay calm and speak reassuringly
Encourage slow breathing and grounding techniques (naming objects, focusing on sensations)
Move to quieter, less crowded space if possible
Stay with person until symptoms ease
Seek medical care if chest pain, collapse or prolonged symptoms occur

documents.name: Acute Grief or Shock Reaction
documents.description: Strong emotional response after receiving traumatic news or experiencing loss
documents.notes: Supportive presence can reduce long‑term psychological effects
steps: Provide quiet and safe environment
Listen actively without interrupting or judging
Offer simple, practical help such as contacting family or arranging transport
Encourage slow breathing if hyperventilating
Recommend follow‑up with mental health or counselling services

documents.name: Self‑Harm or Suicidal Thoughts (Immediate Support)
documents.description: Person expresses desire to harm themselves or end their life
documents.notes: Any mention of suicide should be taken seriously
steps: Ensure immediate safety by removing access to sharp objects, medications or heights if possible
Stay with person and speak calmly, encouraging them to talk about feelings
Avoid judgmental or dismissive statements
Contact emergency services or crisis helpline if risk appears high
Encourage follow‑up with mental health professionals and trusted family or friends

documents.name: Acute Agitation or Aggression
documents.description: State of extreme restlessness, agitation or aggression that may endanger self or others
documents.notes: Personal safety and safety of others is the priority
steps: Keep a safe distance and do not corner the person
Speak calmly and avoid shouting or sudden movements
Remove bystanders from area if possible
If safe, offer choices such as moving to quieter space or sitting down
Seek help from emergency services or trained security/mental health personnel if risk remains high

documents.name: Acute Confusion or Delirium
documents.description: Sudden change in awareness, thinking and perception, often due to medical illness
documents.notes: May be first sign of serious underlying condition like infection or stroke
steps: Ensure environment is safe by removing hazards
Speak slowly and clearly, reorienting person to time, place and who you are
Avoid arguing about mistaken beliefs or hallucinations
Check for medical alert bracelets or information
Seek urgent medical evaluation

documents.name: Minor Kitchen Burn
documents.description: Small superficial burn from contact with hot pans, oil or steam
documents.notes: Early cooling limits tissue damage
steps: Remove hand or area from heat source immediately
Cool burn under cool running water for 10-20 minutes
Remove rings or tight items before swelling starts
Cover with clean, non‑stick dressing or cling film
Monitor for blistering or infection and seek care if burn is large or on face, hands or joints

documents.name: Minor Electrical Shock (Low Voltage)
documents.description: Brief shock from household electricity without persistent symptoms
documents.notes: Cardiac and muscle effects are possible even if injury seems minor
steps: Ensure power source is switched off before touching person
Assess responsiveness and breathing
Check for entry and exit burn marks and cover with clean dressings
Advise medical review, especially in children, pregnant individuals or those with heart disease
Seek urgent help if chest pain, confusion or loss of consciousness occurred

documents.name: Glass Cut
documents.description: Cut from broken glass or sharp household items
documents.notes: Small glass fragments may remain in wound
steps: Rinse wound gently with clean water to remove obvious debris
Apply direct pressure with clean cloth or dressing to control bleeding
Do not explore wound deeply with fingers or tools
Cover with sterile dressing
Seek medical help if cut is deep, edges are gaping or glass may remain inside

documents.name: Chemical Inhalation in Bathroom or Kitchen
documents.description: Breathing in fumes from cleaning agents or mixed chemicals
documents.notes: Never mix bleach with acids or ammonia due to toxic gas formation
steps: Move person immediately to area with fresh air
Open doors and windows if safe to ventilate room
Have person sit upright and breathe slowly
Remove contaminated clothing if strong fumes absorbed
Seek medical care if cough, chest tightness or breathing difficulty persists

documents.name: Minor Eye Irritation from Soap or Shampoo
documents.description: Stinging and watering of eyes after accidental exposure to mild detergents
documents.notes: Usually resolves with thorough rinsing
steps: Rinse eye with clean lukewarm water for several minutes
Ask person to blink frequently during rinsing
Avoid rubbing eyes
Remove contact lenses if present and easily removable
Seek eye care if pain, redness or blurred vision persists

documents.name: Motion Sickness
documents.description: Nausea and dizziness triggered by travel in car, bus, boat or plane
documents.notes: Often improves when motion stops or visual input changes
steps: Have person face forward and look at stable horizon point
Encourage fresh air by opening window or using fan
Offer small sips of water
Avoid heavy meals, alcohol or reading during travel
Use prescribed or over‑the‑counter motion sickness remedies as directed

documents.name: Jet Lag Fatigue
documents.description: Sleep disturbance and fatigue after crossing time zones
documents.notes: Adjusting sleep schedule before travel may reduce severity
steps: Encourage exposure to natural light during daytime at destination
Promote hydration and light meals
Avoid excessive caffeine and alcohol
Advise short naps rather than long daytime sleep
Seek medical advice if severe sleep problems persist

documents.name: Deep Vein Thrombosis Prevention During Travel
documents.description: Measures to reduce risk of blood clots in legs during long journeys
documents.notes: High‑risk individuals should follow doctor’s advice before travel
steps: Encourage leg movement and walking every 1‑2 hours if possible
Perform ankle circles and calf stretches while seated
Avoid tight clothing around waist and legs
Stay well hydrated with water
Seek medical advice for persistent leg swelling, pain or redness after travel

documents.name: Altitude Sickness (Mild)
documents.description: Headache, nausea and fatigue after rapid ascent to high altitudes
documents.notes: Can progress to serious brain or lung swelling if ignored
steps: Rest and avoid further ascent until symptoms improve
Encourage drinking water and avoiding alcohol
Offer light, high‑carbohydrate meals
Consider using approved medications if previously prescribed
Descend to lower altitude and seek medical care if symptoms worsen or do not improve

documents.name: Insect Bites While Traveling (Prevention and Care)
documents.description: Itchy or painful bites from mosquitoes or other insects during travel
documents.notes: In some regions bites may transmit diseases like malaria or dengue
steps: Use insect repellent according to instructions
Wear long sleeves and trousers, especially at dawn and dusk
Sleep under insecticide‑treated bed nets where appropriate
Clean bites with soap and water and avoid scratching
Seek medical care if fever, rash or body pain occurs after bites
